Last modified September 1, 2015

swarm env: Manage Environments

Giant Swarm environments provide separate contextual namespaces in which services can be deployed. Here is a simple example illustrating creating and switching to the prod environment namespace for an organization named startup:

$ swarm org create startup
Organization 'startup' has been created
$ swarm env startup/prod
Environment startup/prod has been selected

When a user signs up for Giant Swarm, they are assigned an organization which carries the same string used as their username. For example, a user named bant will have an organization named bant in their account:

$ swarm user
bant
$ swarm org --list
bant

Note: Organization names are managed using the swarm org command. Organization names are unique across the Giant Swarm shared public cluster. In case of an error while creating an organization, try a different name!

Command Syntax

Viewing Environments

The swarm env command is used without parameters to view the current organization and environment:

$ swarm env
bant/dev

Create and/or Select Evironments

The swarm env command can also be called using the full environment path, which requires an organization name and desired environment name:

swarm env <org_name>/<env_name>

Note: If the given environment namespace does not exist, it will be created before the CLI switches to using the specified environment path.

Listing Environments

The swarm env command can be called with the -l or --list flags to return a list of all available environments for the current user:

$ swarm env -l
   bant/dev
 * startup/prod
   startup/test

Deleting Environments

The swarm env command can be called with the -d or --delete flag to delete a specific environment:

$ swarm env -d startup/test
Environment startup/test has been deleted

Note: Deleting an environment does not delete or stop any services deployed in the environment’s scope. This means it is entirely possible to ‘strand’ services, where they can’t be stopped or deleted. Be careful out there!

Further Reading

  • Managing Organizations
